pullRequest.body:
We add various results needed to prove flt3.

From the flt3 project at LFTCM2024.

---

I've stopped at a random point to keep the PR around 300 lines. The next one will surely be the final one.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/ea0f7a7a-0bbb-4634-a6d0-40ca86fbf612/to/62711af8-08c8-4131-8656-4fb8cb0c5233) against commit dff9f5d732525aed55b9ec6b8cfcc148f35be07b:

```diff
  =======================================================
- ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.FLT.Three   instructions    76.9%
```
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by faenuccio.

:v: riccardobrasca can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9889587082/job/27315986823)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9889587082/job/27315987569)

Thanks a lot! I've left some pernickety comments.

bors d+
A few more nitpicks, and one somewhat deeper question (sorry!) Generally looks fine, though.
I left some minor comments, but overall LGTM.

Thanks a lot! I've left some pernickety comments.

bors d+

All the various `y`, `z`, `w` etc are mathematically arbitrary elements that satisfy the `spec` lemma. Technically, using `choose_spec` we fix one single elements, and all the proofs are wrt this fixed elements, not an arbitrary one. Usually this is a bad idea, but here I think it is OK:
* the notation is nicer (we don't have to keep `{y} (hy)` around
* All the lemmas are useful only to prove flt3, and will never be used for something else.
Sounds like they should be private
Ah sure. Do you know if there is way to make a whole section private?
It [seems](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/private.20section) there is no simple way.

I think this would flow more logically:
```suggestion
  suffices p_lam : p ∣ λ from hp.associated_of_dvd hζ.zeta_sub_one_prime' p_lam
  by_contra p_lam
```
Similar here
Ditto
Should this be local?
Let's give all these a name starting with `isCoprime`
`u_mul_w_cube` for consistency?
Can this use `apply_fun`?

```suggestion
  calc ((η : 𝓞 K) + 1) * -η = -(η ^ 2 + η + 1) + 1 := by ring
```

```suggestion
  · refine (hp.dvd_or_dvd ?_).resolve_left ‹_›
```

```suggestion
  · refine (hp.dvd_or_dvd ?_).resolve_left ‹_›
```

```suggestion
  suffices p_lam : p ∣ λ from hp.associated_of_dvd hζ.zeta_sub_one_prime' p_lam
```

```suggestion
  suffices p_lam : p ∣ λ from hp.associated_of_dvd hζ.zeta_sub_one_prime' p_lam
```

```suggestion
  have h : λ ^ S.multiplicity ∣ S.c := multiplicity.pow_multiplicity_dvd _
```

After reading through the rest of the file... Is this not just `Associated (a ^ 3 + b ^ 3) (c ^ 3)`? (Perhaps we defer checking whether that's an easier formulation after you've landed everything, though.)

Yes, what we prove is that `a ^3 + b ^ 3` and `c ^ 3` cannot be associated in `𝓞 K`. I have the feeling we don't gain anything in using `Associated`: in all proofs we would introduce immediately the unit.
Can this be turned into a link in the docs? (Or is this automatic?)

```suggestion
lemma lambda_sq_not_dvd_a_add_eta_mul_b : ¬ λ ^ 2 ∣ (S.a + η * S.b) := by
```
(needs corresponding changes where used)
Can you use the automorphism `η ↦ η ^ 2` to reduce this to the previous statement?
I've golfed the proof a little, but I don't think there is an easy way of using `η ↦ η ^ 2`: `S.a` and `S.b` are in `𝓞 K`, not in `ℤ`.

Yes, but the automorphism should send solutions to solutions, so one could use the previous lemma for the image (= preimage) of `S` and then apply the automorphism. But it is maybe not so clear that this will save much overall (since one needs some API for the automorphism). So I'm OK with leaving it as is.
Yes, I think the API would be longer, and almost surely useless besides this file.
Didn't you have a lemma somewhere saying that `η ^ 2 + η + 1 = 0` ? Or `η ^ 2 = -η - 1`...
`hpaetab` is hard to read. Maybe `hpaηb` ? :smile:
What about a general lemma that says something like "`p ∣ a*x + b*y` and `p ∣ c*x + d*y` imply that `p` divides `(a*d-b*c) * gcd x y`" ? That could simplify this proof and the next.

```suggestion
    show (S.a + S.b) * (λ * y S) * (λ * z S) = (S.a + S.b) * y S * z S * λ * λ by ring] at h
```

```suggestion
  (multiplicity.pow_multiplicity_dvd S.toSolution'.multiplicity_lambda_c_finite).choose_spec
```
The preceding three proofs are all very similar. Can some common argument be extracted, or are they too different for that?
They're now very short via `isCoprime_helper`. Thanks for the remark, I wouldn't had the energy to do that otherwise, but it is definitely better.

I think it would make sense to generalize [exists_associated_pow_of_mul_eq_pow'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/PrincipalIdealDomain.html#exists_associated_pow_of_mul_eq_pow') to have `Associated (a * b) (c ^ k)` as an assumption and a conjunction (`a` and `b` both are associated to a `k`th power) as the conclusion. Then this could simply be applied twice to get all three statements above.
Done, thanks!

What I had in mind is
```lean
variable {R} [CommRing R] [IsDomain R] [IsBezout R]

theorem exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow {a b c : R} (hab : IsCoprime a b) {k : ℕ}
    (h : Associated (a * b) (c ^ k)) : ∃ d : R, Associated a (d ^ k) := by
  obtain ⟨u, hu⟩ := h
  rw [mul_assoc] at hu
  obtain ⟨x, hx⟩ := exists_associated_pow_of_mul_eq_pow'
    ((isCoprime_mul_unit_right_right u.isUnit a b).mpr hab) hu
  exact ⟨x, hx.symm⟩ -- switching the order to make the output compatible with the input

theorem exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow' {a b c : R} (hab : IsCoprime a b) {k : ℕ}
    (h : Associated (a * b) (c ^ k)) :
    (∃ x : R, Associated a (x ^ k)) ∧ ∃ y : R, Associated b (y ^ k) :=
  ⟨exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow hab h,
    exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow hab.symm (mul_comm a b ▸ h)⟩
```
and then
```lean
private lemma exists_cube_associated : 
    (∃ (X : 𝓞 K), Associated S.x (X ^ 3)) ∧ (∃ (Y : 𝓞 K), Associated S.y (Y ^ 3) ) ∧
      ∃ (Z : 𝓞 K), Associated S.z (Z ^ 3) := by
  obtain ⟨⟨xy, hxy⟩, hz⟩ :=  exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow' ... -- for (S.x * S.y) * S.z ~ S.w ^ 3
  obtain ⟨hx, hy⟩ := exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow' S.isCoprime_x_y hxy
  exact ⟨hx, hy, hz⟩
```
where the arguments to the first `exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow'` need to be filled in (something like `IsCoprime.mul_left S.isCoprime_x_z S.isCoprime_y_z` and the statement `Associated (S.x * S.y * S.z) (S.w ^ 3)`, which is still proved three times in the current code (in slight variations)).
(See [here](https://live.lean-lang.org/#code=import%20Mathlib%0A%0Avariable%20%7BR%7D%20%5BCommRing%20R%5D%20%5BIsDomain%20R%5D%20%5BIsBezout%20R%5D%0A%0Atheorem%20exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow%20%7Ba%20b%20c%20%3A%20R%7D%20(hab%20%3A%20IsCoprime%20a%20b)%20%7Bk%20%3A%20%E2%84%95%7D%0A%20%20%20%20(h%20%3A%20Associated%20(a%20*%20b)%20(c%20%5E%20k))%20%3A%20%E2%88%83%20d%20%3A%20R%2C%20Associated%20a%20(d%20%5E%20k)%20%3A%3D%20by%0A%20%20obtain%20%E2%9F%A8u%2C%20hu%E2%9F%A9%20%3A%3D%20h%0A%20%20rw%20%5Bmul_assoc%5D%20at%20hu%0A%20%20obtain%20%E2%9F%A8x%2C%20hx%E2%9F%A9%20%3A%3D%20exists_associated_pow_of_mul_eq_pow'%0A%20%20%20%20((isCoprime_mul_unit_right_right%20u.isUnit%20a%20b).mpr%20hab)%20hu%0A%20%20exact%20%E2%9F%A8x%2C%20hx.symm%E2%9F%A9%0A%0Atheorem%20exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow'%20%7Ba%20b%20c%20%3A%20R%7D%20(hab%20%3A%20IsCoprime%20a%20b)%20%7Bk%20%3A%20%E2%84%95%7D%0A%20%20%20%20(h%20%3A%20Associated%20(a%20*%20b)%20(c%20%5E%20k))%20%3A%0A%20%20%20%20(%E2%88%83%20x%20%3A%20R%2C%20Associated%20a%20(x%20%5E%20k))%20%E2%88%A7%20%E2%88%83%20y%20%3A%20R%2C%20Associated%20b%20(y%20%5E%20k)%20%3A%3D%0A%20%20%E2%9F%A8exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow%20hab%20h%2C%0A%20%20%20%20exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow%20hab.symm%20(mul_comm%20a%20b%20%E2%96%B8%20h)%E2%9F%A9%0A%20%20%0A%0Avariable%20%7Bw%20x%20y%20z%20%3A%20R%7D%20(H%20%3A%20Associated%20(x%20*%20y%20*%20z)%20(w%20%5E%203))%0A%0Avariable%20(Hxy%20%3A%20IsCoprime%20x%20y)%20(Hxz%20%3A%20IsCoprime%20x%20z)%20(Hyz%20%3A%20IsCoprime%20y%20z)%0A%0Alemma%20exists_cube_associated%20%3A%20%0A%20%20%20%20(%E2%88%83%20X%2C%20Associated%20x%20(X%20%5E%203))%20%E2%88%A7%20(%E2%88%83%20Y%2C%20Associated%20y%20(Y%20%5E%203))%20%E2%88%A7%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%E2%88%83%20Z%2C%20Associated%20z%20(Z%20%5E%203)%20%3A%3D%20by%0A%20%20obtain%20%E2%9F%A8%E2%9F%A8xy%2C%20hxy%E2%9F%A9%2C%20hz%E2%9F%A9%20%3A%3D%0A%20%20%20%20exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow'%20(IsCoprime.mul_left%20Hxz%20Hyz)%20H%0A%20%20obtain%20%E2%9F%A8hx%2C%20hy%E2%9F%A9%20%3A%3D%20exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow'%20Hxy%20hxy%0A%20%20exact%20%E2%9F%A8hx%2C%20hy%2C%20hz%E2%9F%A9%0A%0A).)
(The names may need some permuting to fit with the changed order in `Associated` in the statements.)

Let me think a little bit about it, but:
* I think the conclusion of `exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow` should be `Associated (d ^ k) a` (and not the other way) to match the one of `exists_associated_pow_of_mul_eq_pow'`. But indeed the assumption should be `Associated (c ^ k) (a * b)` to match the order.
* I am not completely sure it is worth to add `exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow'`: it is basically a twe copies of the umprimed version, and if needed can be inlined.
I've proved your `exists_cube_associated` essentially as you proposed, but without adding `exists_associated_pow_of_associated_mul_pow'`. Thanks for the suggestion!
I realized this for a modification that at end I did in another file. I think it doesn't hurt.
Why are you finaling removing the private attribute?
Because I need it in the other file.
Stupid question: are the two lemma below false in the non-commutative setting?

TBH I don't know, the proof surely doesn't work (in practice you introduce `k1` and `k2`, write the two relations as a matrix multiplication, multiply by the adjugate matrix and the determinant does its magic: this only works over commutative rings).

```suggestion
The strategy is the following:
```

```suggestion
  enough to prove that this equation has no solutions such that `c ≠ 0`, `¬ λ ∣ a`, `¬ λ ∣ b`,
```
Can you say what is lambda in this doc?

```suggestion
  have hh := multiplicity.is_greatest' S.toSolution'.multiplicity_lambda_c_finite
```
Perhaps you could add a couple (not a thousand...) of pointers to the code, explaining how to bridge the informal-formal gap between your explanation above and what happens below.
I've added a pointer to `exists_Solution_of_Solution'`. The rest of the argument will be formalized in the final PR and I will add more pointers.
Thanks! Then I have nothing more to comment, I believe.
shuold it be `...of_associated_mul_pow` or `...of_associated_pow_mul`? In general, what is the naming convention for associated things?
You're right, I switched the order at some point and didn't change the name.

Slight simplification:
```suggestion
  obtain ⟨u, hu⟩ := h.symm
  rw [mul_assoc] at hu
  exact exists_associated_pow_of_mul_eq_pow'
    ((isCoprime_mul_unit_right_right u.isUnit a b).mpr hab) hu
```

```suggestion
lemma dvd_mul_sub_mul_mul_right_of_dvd {p a b c d x y : R}
    (h1 : p ∣ a * x + b * y) (h2 : p ∣ c * x + d * y) : p ∣ (a * d - b * c) * y :=
  (mul_comm a _ ▸ mul_comm c _ ▸ dvd_mul_sub_mul_mul_left_of_dvd 
    (add_comm (c * x) _ ▸ h2) (add_comm (a * x) _ ▸ h1))
```
What do you think about deducing it from the previous lemma? This proof is about twice as fast and doesn't involve any fancy tactics like `ring`, but I'm ambivalent about whether it's better.
`polyrith` solves this in one line now, as does `  linear_combination d * hk1 - b * hk2`, but neither is imported :-/ I guess this more low-level way works.
Yes, I thought about that, but I think this is so easy with `ring` that it is not worth to add a new `import`.
